"SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE." The Congress finds that the Brown v. Board of Education decision was significant in ending school segregation. The admission of the Little Rock Nine to Central High School furthered integration in public schools. Central High School in the United States, named the most beautiful high school building by the American Institute of Architects, was designated a national historic landmark in 1982 for its role in the civil rights movement. The Act aims to preserve and interpret the significant role of Little Rock Central High School in the desegregation of public schools in the South and its contribution to the civil rights movement in the United States. Establishment of Central High School National Historic Site. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as part of the National Park System in Arkansas. The site includes the Central High School campus in Little Rock and will be administered by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary will administer the historic site in accordance with relevant laws. The Little Rock School District retains authority over Little Rock Central High School. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private entities. The Secretary will administer the historic site in coordination with the Little Rock School District and Central High School Museum. Within 2 years, a general management plan will be prepared for the site, with a focus on continuing educational use in consultation with the school district. The Secretary will coordinate with the Little Rock School District to develop a management plan for the historic site without disrupting Central High School's educational activities. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands within the site with consent from the owner, except for lands owned by the State of Arkansas or its subdivisions, which can only be acquired through donation or exchange. SEC. 3. DESEGREGATION IN PUBLIC EDUCATION THEME STUDY. The Secretary is required to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education within 2 years. The study will identify sites and structures that commemorate key events in the movement for racial desegregation in public education. The Secretary will identify new national historic landmarks related to desegregation in public education and prepare a list of sites for landmark designation. The theme study will also establish linkages between these sites and the Central High School National Historic Site for education and research opportunities. The theme study will recommend opportunities for public education and research on desegregation in public education, as well as cooperative agreements with relevant entities to preserve key historical sites. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions, public history organizations, or civil rights organizations knowledgeable about desegregation to ensure scholarly standards are met. The theme study for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site will be prepared in coordination with the general management plan to ensure scholarly standards are met. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this Act.
